en.labText1: Incoming transmission… Robot 419, do you read us?
en.labText2: Your mission today: travel back to America in the early 1800s and learn all you can about Manifest Destiny and witness firsthand America’s westward expansion.
en.labText3: Start by collecting the letter and the time travel device on the table in front of you. Tap the screen or click to move closer.
en.labText4: This letter was sent back by our Correspondence Bot, currently stationed in the 1800s. Let’s open it and see what it says.
en.labText6: Manifest Destiny was the 19th-century belief that it was the United States 'Obvious Fate' to expand across all of North America. Coined by journalist John O’Sullivan in 1845, it claimed Americans had a divine duty to spread democracy and liberty.
en.labText7: This idea was used to ignore land claims by Great Britain, Mexico, and Indigenous peoples. Supporters believed expansion was part of God’s plan, even if it meant using force or unfair tactics.
en.labText8: By 1848, the U.S. had tripled in size, gaining land through treaties, settlements, deception, and war, all in the name of spreading American values.
en.labText9: I've placed this information in a book in your inventory. There is a button at the top right of he screen to open it. Let's do that now.
en.labText10: You can see there is a book in your inventory. Let's open it.
en.labText11: This book contains all the information we learned in the correspondence bot's letter. You can close it with the small X button in the top right of the book.
en.labText12: Okay. Let's head back to 1803 with our time travel device. Please push the big red button when ready.
en.book1BP1: In the 1800s, many Americans believed it was their country’s 'obvious fate' to grow across the whole continent.
en.book1BP2: A man named John O’Sullivan came up with the phrase 'Manifest Destiny' in 1845.
en.book1BP3: People thought it was their duty from God to spread freedom and democracy to new lands.
en.book1BP4: This belief was used to ignore the rights of Great Britain, Mexico, and Indigenous peoples who already lived on the land.
en.book1BP5: Some Americans believed that expansion was right, even if it meant using force or unfair methods.
en.book1BP6: By 1848, the United States had tripled in size through treaties, settlements, trickery, and war.
en.book2BP1: America is destined to expand westward and claim new land. Our young nation didn’t begin to grow through war — we grew with smart deals and brave settlers.
en.book2BP2: A man named James Monroe was sent to buy New Orleans for our farmers. Napoleon and France surprised us — they sold the US all of Louisiana instead! This peaceful deal doubled the country size.
en.book2BP3: In Texas, Americans moved in with Mexico’s permission. They promised to follow the rules — no fighting, just settlement.
en.book2BP4: Out west, Lewis and Clark explored new lands. Later, a path known as the South Pass made it easier for wagons to reach Oregon. As more settlers arrived, so did our claim.
en.book3BP1: In the early 1800s, farmers needed the Mississippi River and the port of New Orleans to sell their crops. If they lost access, they couldn’t make money.
en.book3BP2: The land west of the river—Louisiana—was owned by France. Farmers worried Napoleon might close New Orleans and stop their trade.
en.book3BP3: After losing a colony in Haiti, Napoleon changed his mind and the British were approaching. Instead of just New Orleans, he considered selling the whole Louisiana Territory.
en.book3BP4: President Jefferson sent James Monroe to buy New Orleans for $10 million. But Napoleon offered the whole Louisiana Territory for $15 million!
en.book4BP1: Political Motivation: Many Americans believed in Manifest Destiny—the idea that the U.S. had a right to expand west and spread democracy and freedom.
en.book4BP2: Willing to Confront Rivals: The U.S. was prepared to challenge powerful nations like Great Britain and Mexico to fulfill its expansion goals.
en.book4BP3: Economic Opportunity: Western lands like Louisiana and Oregon promised valuable resources, trade routes, and fertile farmland for settlers.
en.book4BP4: Cultural Beliefs: Americans believed it was their God-given duty to spread their way of life, seeing themselves as culturally and morally superior.
en.citationInfoBook1: Manifest Destiny and the Growing Nation - Introduction - Page 1
en.stage1Text1: Wow, we're really in 1803. There's a piece of paper on the ground here. Let's read it!
en.stage1Text2: We need to find Thomas Jefferson. Could you please search the camp for a wooden sign with the meaning of “Manifest Destiny” written on it?
en.stage1Text3: Does this sign have the meaning of the term 'Manifest Destiny' written on it?
en.stage1Text4: It sounds correct, but it isn’t. Have a look at the book in your inventory and try again.
en.stage1Text5: That's correct. Manifest Destiny means 'Obvious Fate'. Oh look, Thomas Jefferson is here and approaching us. Let's talk to him.
en.thomasJefferson1Pretext: My name is Thomas Jefferson. I have written you a letter. Will you please read it? Then I have a task I need you to complete for me.
en.thomasJefferson1Letter1: America is destined to expand westward and claim new land. Our young nation didn’t begin to grow through war — we grew with smart deals and brave settlers.
en.thomasJefferson2Letter2: I sent a man named James Monroe to buy New Orleans for our farmers. Napoleon and France surprised us — they sold us all of Louisiana instead! One peaceful deal doubled our country.
en.thomasJefferson3Letter3: In Texas, Americans moved in with Mexico’s permission. They promised to follow the rules — no fighting, just settlement.  Out west, Lewis and Clark explored new lands. Later, a path known as the South Pass made it easier for wagons to reach Oregon. As more settlers arrived, so did our claim.
en.thomasJefferson4Letter4: We used exploration, trade, and peaceful agreements — not armies — to begin to shape America’s future.
en.thomasJeffersonWesternPrior1: One of my great hopes for westward expansion is to open trade routes stretching from the Mississippi River all the way to the Pacific Ocean. Such paths would link our farms and cities to new ports and markets.
en.thomasJeffersonWesternPrior2: Along the way, we must greet the native nations with respect. Through fair trade and cultural exchange, I believe we can build trust and friendship as we journey west.
en.thomasJeffersonWesternPrior3: I have written down these priorities for westward expansion, but I have left them around camp. Can you please search through the tents and crates to see if you can find them? There should be 3 to find.
en.stage1Scene2MiniGame2Text: Find 3 of Thomas Jefferson's priorities for Westward Expansion. Look through the crates in camp.
en.stage1Scene2MiniGame2Question: Is this one of Thomas Jefferson's priorities for Westward Expansion?
en.stage1Scene2MiniGame2InCorrect: Are you sure? Have a look at the books in your inventory and try again!
en.stage1Scene2MiniGame2Correct1: Correct, Thomas Jefferson prioritized creating trade routes along the Mississippi to reach the Pacific Ocean.
en.stage1Scene2MiniGame2Correct2: Correct, Thomas Jefferson saw greeting the natives and gaining good relations as a priority for westward expansion.
en.stage1Scene2MiniGame2Correct3: Correct, offering trade and a cultural exchange with the natives as a priority for westward expansion.
en.stage1Scene2MiniGame2Answer1: Offer native tribes trade and a cultural exchange.
en.stage1Scene2MiniGame2Answer2: Create trade routes along the Mississippi.
en.stage1Scene2MiniGame2Answer3: Greet native tribes and gain good relations.
en.stage1Scene2MiniGame2Answer4: Collect types of rocks to study back home.
en.stage1Scene2MiniGame2Complete: That's all 3 priorities collected. Let us head back to talk to Thomas Jefferson.
en.stage1Scene2MoveToParis: I have sent James Monroe to Paris to talk to Napoleon. Could you please head there now and see how the negotiations are progressing?
en.stage1Scene3Start: We’ve been transported to Napoleon's study in Paris. There's a letter here. Let’s read it!
en.napoleonLetter1: In the early 1800s, American farmers were moving west. They used the Mississippi River to send crops to market through the port of New Orleans. It was super important — without it, they couldn’t sell their food.
en.napoleonLetter2: The land west of the river was called Louisiana. It belonged to France, led by Napoleon. He wanted to use the land to help feed his Caribbean colonies. But farmers were worried — if Napoleon closed New Orleans, they were stuck.
en.napoleonLetter3: Then, something big happened. In Haiti, formerly enslaved people led by Toussaint L’Ouverture defeated the French. Napoleon no longer needed Louisiana, and with a war against Britain coming, he decided to sell the land instead of risking losing it.
en.napoleonLetter4: President Jefferson sent James Monroe to buy New Orleans for $10 million. But Napoleon offered the whole Louisiana Territory for $15 million! That’s double the land for a great price.
en.napoleonLetter5: Some Americans didn’t like it — they thought it was too much land or that it broke the rules of the Constitution. But most people were excited. In 1804, Lewis and Clark set off to explore the new land, with help from a Shoshone woman named Sacagawea.
en.stage1Scene3Talks: Napoleon and Monroe are starting negotiations. Let's take part in the talks and see if we can help them come to an agreement.
en.taskStage1Scene3: Take control of Napoleon and Monroe and choose what each one should say in the discussion of the Louisiana Purchase.
en.napoleonChoice1a: War with Britain is coming, we must act swiftly, before the British seize our lands.
en.napoleonChoice1b: I think keeping hold of Lousianna is the best idea, in case we win the war with Britain
en.monroeChoice1a: We are prepared to purchase New Orleans.
en.monroeChoice1b: What are your intentions with Louisiana?
en.napoleonChoice2a: I will sell all of Louisiana for $15 million.
en.napoleonChoice2b: I can part with New Orleans for $10 million.
en.monroeChoiceBuyLouisiana: Success! For just $15 million, Monroe buys the entire Louisiana Territory, doubling the size of the U.S. and securing control of the Mississippi River!
en.monroeChoiceBuyOrleans: Monroe gets the port of New Orleans, but the vast Louisiana Territory stays in French hands. The U.S. misses a huge chance to expand west. Try again.
en.textToMoveToScene1Stage4: Let's head back to the US and tell Thomas Jefferson the great news!
en.stage1Scene4Text1: Welcome Back. I’ve just been told the great news about Louisiana.
en.stage1Scene4Text2: Now we should start looking at exploring it.
en.stage1Scene4Text3: But before we do, this letter arrived for you. Take a look!
en.stage1Scene4Text4: Meet Lewis and Clark. These brave explorers are going to map out and chart a route from Illinois all the way west to the pacific ocean.
en.stage1Scene4Text5: But we need your help. On the table there is a map of the US.
en.stage1Scene4Text6: We need you to look at it and help us make decisions on what Lewis and Clark should do along the way.
en.stage1Scene4Text7: When you're ready. Approach the map.
en.politicalEcoCultureLetter1: Politically, the U.S. believed it was its Manifest Destiny to expand westward. Many Americans thought they had a right to spread U.S. political ideals—like democracy and freedom—to new lands. They were also willing to challenge other nations, such as Great Britain and Mexico, to achieve this goal.
en.politicalEcoCultureLetter2: Economically, gaining control of areas like Louisiana, the Oregon Territory, and western lands offered valuable resources, new trade routes, and fertile farmland. These were key economic reasons that motivated many settlers to move west.
en.politicalEcoCultureLetter3: Culturally, a major reason for expansion was the belief in American superiority and divine right. Many people felt it was “God’s plan” for Americans to spread west, and they believed it was their moral duty to bring their way of life to new territories.
en.maptext1: This is a map of the US in 1803.
en.maptext2: The green area represents the United States. The yellow shows the newly acquired Louisiana Territory. The red marks land owned by Spain, and the pink represents Spanish-controlled Florida.
en.maptext3: We need to plan a route for Lewis and Clark. From here in Illinois, all the way to the Pacific Ocean.
en.maptext4: Firstly we need to know which direction we want Lewis and Clark to explore.
en.mapDecisionAnswerWrong: We could expand in that direction but it wouldn't fulfil the dream of Manifest Destiny.
en.mapDecisionAnswerCorrect: Excellent, we should definitely expand west. Let's head to the Mississippi river on the Lousianna border.
en.mapDecision2Text1: At the Mississippi River, you meet a Shoshone woman named Sacagawea and an Indigenous tribe living on the land. What should we do?
en.mapDecision2Answer2: Try to make peace and allow sacagawea to accompany you on the journey to the pacific coast. Her knowledge of the land could come in vitally useful.
en.mapDecision2AnswerWrong: Trying to take their land by force will cause tension and violence. Maybe there is another way we can approach this scenario.
en.mapDecision2AnswerCorrect: Excellent, Trying to make peace and spread Democracy fulfils one of Thomas Jeffersons priorities for Westward Expansion. With Sacagawea with us, we’ll be able to navigate the rough terrain much safer.  Let's move onto the Rocky Mountains.
en.mapDecision3Text1: At the Rocky Mountains, you discover the land is too rough. Should we keep going?
en.mapDecision3Answer1: Yes, it is our obvious fate and God's plan.
en.mapDecision3Answer3: No, we should turn around and go back.
en.mapDecision3AnswerWrong1: If we stop here we’ll never know what lies behind the Rocky Mountains.
en.mapDecision3AnswerWrong2: If we turn back we wont expand american westward and others might claim the land before us.
en.mapDecision3AnswerCorrect: Well done. It is America's obvious fate and God's plan to expand west, no matter how tough it gets. Let's cross carefully and reach the pacific coast.
en.mapComplete: We’ve made it to the pacific coast. Now we know the route, other settlers can follow in our foot steps and America can spread from the east coast all the way to the west.
en.mapComplete2: Lets travel forward in time and join the settlers on the Oregon Trail.
